Introduction 

Hip fractures are common injuries that involve a break in the proximal femur.  They are classified as either intracapsular, which involve the femoral head and neck, or extracapsular, which involve the intertrochanteric or subtrochanteric regions.  Hip fractures most often occur in elderly adults (age >65) following a fall.  Patients typically present with severe hip or groin pain, an inability to ambulate, and a leg that is shortened and externally rotated on the affected side.  Hip fractures generally require surgical correction.

Anatomy



The hip joint is a ball-and-socket joint formed by the head of the femur (the ball) and the acetabulum of the pelvis (the socket).  The joint is enclosed by a fibrous capsule, which contains synovial fluid to lubricate and nourish the joint.  The capsule originates from the acetabulum and inserts onto the femur at the base of the distal femoral neck.



The femoral head and neck are located inside the joint capsule (ie, intracapsular) and are perfused by a delicate group of vessels (supplied mainly by medial femoral circumflex artery) that encircle the base of the femoral neck then pass through the capsule to reach the femoral head.  When an intracapsular fracture occurs, it can disrupt this tenuous blood flow, increasing the risk of avascular necrosis of the femoral head and malunion/nonunion (poor fracture healing) (

The intertrochanteric and subtrochanteric regions of the femur are located outside the joint capsule (ie, extracapsular).  These areas are mainly composed of cancellous bone, which has a more stable blood supply, and these fractures typically heal well with proper surgical repair.

Pathogenesis



Hip fractures are usually the result of mechanical trauma.  When an impact or force exceeds the bone's capacity to withstand stress, a fracture occurs.  In younger individuals, these fractures are usually caused by high-impact incidents such as motor vehicle accidents or falls from significant heights.  In contrast, hip fractures in the elderly are often the result of low-energy falls from standing and decreased bone density (osteoporosis).

Risk factors



  • Advanced age:  This is the primary risk factor due to age-related decline in bone density and muscle strength.
  • Osteoporosis:  Osteoporosis is a major factor in bone fragility, increasing susceptibility to fractures from low-energy trauma.
  • Female sex:  The risk increases due to postmenopausal osteoporosis and a longer life expectancy.
  • Previous falls:  Balance problems and a history of falls are predictors for future fractures.
  • Sedentary lifestyle:  Inactivity contributes to muscle atrophy and decreased bone density.
  • Chronic conditions:  Parkinson disease, vertigo, stroke, and vision impairment increase fall risk.
  • Medications:  Sedatives, antipsychotics, and antihypertensives may contribute to instability and falls.
  • Alcohol and tobacco use:  Both substances are associated with poor bone health and increased fall risk.

Pathology



Hip fractures are categorized by their anatomic location on the femur (

image 1
):



  • Femoral head and neck fractures (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ):

    • Intracapsular fractures that involve the femoral head and/or the area between the femoral head and the greater trochanter (ie, neck)
    • Associated with increased risk of avascular necrosis and malunion/nonunion because the femoral neck has a thin periosteum and a tenuous blood supply that can be damaged by hip fracture or dislocation
  • Intertrochanteric fracture:
    • Extracapsular fracture between the greater and lesser trochanters
    • Mostly cancellous bone with a good blood supply; therefore, these fractures typically heal well with fewer complications than femoral neck fractures
  • Subtrochanteric fracture:
    • Extracapsular fracture below the trochanteric region, typically due to high-energy trauma
    • Well-perfused area of bone, but these fractures tend to be unstable; also, there is a higher rate of postrepair failure due to high stress in this area


Femoral neck and intertrochanteric fractures are the most common hip fractures in older adults.

Clinical presentation



Patients with hip fractures typically present with:



  • Pain and tenderness:  localized to the hip or groin area, aggravated by movement.
  • Inability to bear weight:  most patients cannot stand or walk on the affected leg.
  • Deformity:  with displaced fractures, the affected leg may appear shortened and externally rotated, primarily due to contraction of the psoas and iliacus without the normal acetabular counterforce (
    figure 1
    ).
  • Swelling or bruising:  may be visible around the hip or upper thigh.  Significant ecchymosis is more common with extracapsular fractures.  In contrast, intracapsular fractures typically have little bruising because fracture-related hemorrhage is contained with the joint capsule.

Differential diagnosis



  • Isolated fracture of the greater trochanter:  can occur due to a ground-level fall in older patients.  Typical features include pain with abduction and tenderness at the trochanter.  Leg length is not affected.
  • Posterior hip dislocation:  most often results from an axial force on the femur (eg, dashboard injury) and presents with adduction and internal (not external) rotation at the hip.  Patients may also have neurologic manifestations due to involvement of the sciatic nerve.
  • Pelvic fracture:  may occur from minor trauma in elderly patients with decreased bone density and present with hip/pelvis pain that is worse with movement.  However, patients with low-impact pelvic fractures typically lack the classic deformities observed with hip fractures.
  • Greater trochanteric pain syndrome:  typically presents with chronic, rather than acute, lateral hip pain that is exacerbated by hip flexion (eg, climbing stairs, getting out of the car) or lying on the affected side.  Pain is typically elicited by palpating over the greater trochanter.
  • Trochanteric bursitis:  causes hip pain but without trauma history, deformity, or the inability to bear weight.

Diagnosis



Hip fractures should be suspected in patients (particularly the elderly) who report hip pain after trauma (eg, fall) and are unable to ambulate, have limited range of motion, and/or exhibit an externally rotated and shortened leg.  Elderly patients with dementia or other cognitive impairment may be unable to disclose a traumatic injury, so a high index of suspicion for hip fracture is required in this population.  The diagnosis is confirmed with imaging.

Imaging studies



Patients with suspected hip fractures should undergo radiographic imaging.



  • X-ray:  the primary diagnostic tool to confirm a hip fracture.  The majority of fractures can be diagnosed using an anterior-posterior (AP) and lateral x-ray of the hip.  An AP pelvis is also helpful to compare the appearance of bilateral hips.  Findings may include shortening or angulation of the femoral neck (
    image 2
    ) and cortical defects or abnormal lucencies in the bone (
    image 3
    ).
  • CT scan:  may be used to detect subtle fractures not evident on initial x-ray or when the fracture pattern is complex and/or additional abdominopelvic injuries (eg, pelvis fracture) are suspected.
  • MRI:  used to detect occult fractures that are not visible on x-ray.


CT or MRI should always be considered in patients with persistent post-traumatic hip pain and normal x-rays.  IN addition, patients must be evaluated for concomitant traumatic injuries, with additional imaging (eg, chest x-ray, CT head, CT cervical spine) obtained as needed.

Laboratory evaluation



Laboratory tests are typically required for pre-operative assessment, particularly in older patients with multiple comorbidities.  In addition, when assessing patients after a fall, it is essential to consider syncope and investigate potential contributing medical conditions (eg, cardiac arrhythmia) as the cause of the fall.



  • Complete blood count (CBC):  assess baseline hemoglobin to prepare for potential blood loss during surgical repair
  • Electrolytes and renal function:  required before administering anesthetics/pain medications (for renal clearance)
  • Coagulation profile:  for patients on anticoagulants or those with a clotting disorder
  • Cardiac enzymes:  should be considered if syncope or cardiovascular disease is a concern (ECG is also necessary)
  • Type and screen:  for patients at higher risk of blood loss anemia (eg, age >75, hemoglobin <12g/dL)
  • Bone health markers:  serum calcium and vitamin D levels to evaluate underlying osteoporosis (typically done in the post acute setting)

Management



The primary goal of treatment is to promptly restore the patient's mobility and function and to avoid complications such as avascular necrosis of the femoral head.

Operative management



The definitive management for most hip fractures is surgical repair.  Early surgical intervention (within 24-48 hours) is associated with improved outcomes, including decreased mortality, a shorter hospital stay with fewer complications (eg, pneumonia, deep vein thrombosis), better pain relief, and faster time to ambulation and functional recovery.



Surgery may be briefly delayed in patients with acutely unstable medical conditions (eg, active infection, unstable angina), but delays >72 hours are associated with increased risk of complications and mortality and should be avoided whenever possible.



Antibiotic prophylaxis should be administered to prevent orthopedic surgical site infection (particularly against Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus, and S epidermidis).



Surgical interventions vary based on fracture location and severity as well as the patient's age and functional status (

figure 2
).  Options for repair include:



  • Hemiarthroplasty or total hip replacement:  management of choice for displaced intracapsular fractures in elderly patients, because it eliminates the risk of avascular necrosis (by providing an artificial femoral head).  Total hip replacement is preferred over hemiarthroplasty in more active patients, as it is a more stable and resilient repair.
  • Open reduction with internal fixation:  stabilizes the fracture with metal pins and screws; used more often in younger patients with strong bone quality, nondisplaced fractures, and extracapsular fractures (which have an overall lower risk for avascular necrosis). 


Early mobilization and weight-bearing exercises are encouraged post-surgery to reduce complications.  Physical therapy can improve strength, balance, and range of motion.

Nonoperative management 



Nonoperative management (eg, pain control, immobilization) is associated with significantly higher mortality (eg, 4-fold increase at 1 year) and worse functional outcomes.  However, this approach may be appropriate in certain patient populations:



  • End-stage terminal illness
  • Severe dementia
  • Nonambulatory or poor functional status prior to fracture
  • Major comorbidities that cannot be stabilized


Advanced age alone is not a contraindication to surgery.

Complications



Potential complications associated with hip fractures include:



  • Avascular necrosis of the femoral head:  more likely with intracapsular fractures due to femoral neck vessel disruption and decreased bone perfusion.  Symptoms include gradual-onset hip pain (worse with weight bearing) and decreased range of motion.  X-rays may be normal initially, so MRI is the study of choice for diagnosis.
  • Nonunion or malunion:  reduced perfusion (from vessel injury) leads to inadequate bone healing; nonunion/malunion may also occur with a poor surgical fixation.
  • Dislocation of hip arthroplasty:  there is increased risk of dislocation after hip replacement because the anatomic hip joint stabilizers (eg, ligaments) are often disrupted during surgery.


Additional complications include infection (eg, wound infection, pneumonia), venous thromboembolism (due to immobility and surgery), bleeding/anemia, and delirium.

Prognosis



Mortality rates after hip fracture are higher in elderly patients, and the first year post-fracture carries the most significant risk.  Factors that increase mortality include age >85, male sex, and development of postoperative complications (eg, infection).



Functional outcomes depend on the patient's baseline health and rehabilitation efforts, but only about half of patients regain their baseline mobility and independence after a hip fracture.  Many people require assistance with at least one activity of daily living.



Younger patients tend to have better outcomes but still require close monitoring for avascular necrosis and nonunion.

Prevention



Hip fracture prevention involves the following strategies:



  • Fall prevention:  Home modifications such as removing trip hazards, adding handrails, and improving lighting.  Balance training and exercises to improve muscle strength.
  • Osteoporosis management:  Regular screening for at-risk populations.  Calcium and vitamin D supplementation, along with weight-bearing exercises, are recommended in at-risk populations to maintain bone density.  Medications (eg, bisphosphonates) may be beneficial for high-risk individuals.

Summary 



Hip fractures involve a break in the proximal femur that most often occurs in the elderly after a fall.  Patients typically have hip and groin pain and are unable to ambulate or move the hip without pain.  A shortened and externally rotated leg is characteristic of a displaced hip fracture, and the diagnosis is confirmed with imaging.  Surgical repair is the treatment of choice in most patients, with the goal to restore mobility and function.  Avascular necrosis and nonunion are potential complications that occur when blood vessels at the femoral neck are damaged by fracture.
